12. The study of morals, in the Stoic and in all other sys- tems of philosophy since the time of Socrates, began with an inquiry into the idea of the highest good, the τέλος or summum bonum ; for the question of the highest moral duty of man is identical with that of the highest good, and this with that of happiness; for happiness is the possession of the good, and the good is that which all desire. What is then the good, and what is the highest good, the end and rule of human action (Stob. Ecl. Eth. II. p. 56 τέλος οὗ ἕνεκα πάντα πράττεται καθηκόντως, αὐτὸ δε πράττεται οὐδενὸς ἕνεκα)2

13. Every living being, so they reason, is endowed by nature with the instinct of sels-love and sels-preservation, impelling it to seek that which satisfies and is necessary for its own nature (Diog. Manis further- more endowed with reason distinguishing him from the brute creation3 nothing can therefore bc yood for him which does not satisfyhis reason.
